person.desc: Hilary Bailey is a British writer and editor, born in 1936. She is the author of a biography of Vera Brittain, she edited volumes 7-10 of the New Worlds Quarterly series and among her varied works are 19 books of fiction, including famously Frankenstein's Bride, the sequel to Mary Shelley's Frankenstein, Mrs Rochester, the sequel to Jane Eyre, and Fifty-First State (2008).
person.note: lives in London with her husband, Michael Moorcock, and their two daughters. She is presently working on a novel.

person.desc: an American writer and literary critic. His work includes fiction (especially science fiction), memoir, criticism, and essays on science fiction, literature, sexuality, and society.
person.note: is currently living in New York.

person.desc: Dorman published approximately two dozen science fiction stories between 1961 and 1980, gathering three of these as a young adult novel, Planet Patrol, in 1978; she also published fiction in The Saturday Evening Post, Redbook, and other nonspecialist magazines. Dorman was particularly associated with science fiction's "New Wave" of edgy, experimental writing and indeed, her short story "Go, Go, Go, Said the Bird" was featured in Harlan Ellison's groundbreaking Dangerous Visions anthology (1967). Her experimental novel Onyx was rejected by publishers in 1971, but her collected Poems appeared in 1970, followed by Palace of Earth (1984), Constellations of the Inner Eye (1961), Carrying What You Love (1966), and other volumes of poetry. She moved to Taos, New Mexico in 1986, publishing once again under her maiden name, and died there at eighty. Dorman's recognition from the science fiction community includes a 1978 Science Fiction Poetry Association Rhysling Award for "The Corruption of Metals", and a 1995 James Tiptree, Jr. retroactive award for "When I Was Miss Dow" (1963, reprinted in Galaxy 1966).
person.note: 's book, Poems was recently published by the Ohio University Press.

person.desc: Gordon Eklund is an American science fiction author whose works include the "Lord Tedric" series and two of the earliest original novels based on the 1960s Star Trek TV series. He has written under the pen name Wendell Stewart, and in one instance under the name of the late E. E. "Doc" Smith.
person.note: lives in Berkeley with his wife and child, and recently finished and sold his first novel.

person.desc: Michael John Harrison, known for publication purposes primarily as M. John Harrison, is an English author and literary critic. His work includes the Viriconium sequence of novels and short stories, Climbers, and the Kefahuchi Tract trilogy, which consists of Light, Nova Swing and Empty Space.
person.note: lives in London. His work has appeared on both sides of the Atlantic, and he is working on his first novel.
's novel, Ghost Story, is scheduled to appear this spring. His work has been in Orbit, and will be in Again, Dangerous Visions.

person.desc: Virginia Kidd was an American literary agent, writer and editor, who worked in particular in science fiction and related fields. She represented science fiction American authors such as Ursula K. Le Guin, R.A. Lafferty, Anne McCaffrey, Judith Merril, and Gene Wolfe.
person.note: lives in Milford, Pennsylvania, from where she edits Kinesis, a poetry magazine. Her work has appeared in Orbit, and she is working on a novel.

person.desc: Raphael Aloysius "R. A." Lafferty was an American science fiction and fantasy writer known for his original use of language, metaphor, and narrative structure, Lafferty also wrote a set of four autobiographical novels, a history book, and several novels of historical fiction.
person.note: is the author of Past Master, The Reefs of Earth, and Fourth Mansions.

person.desc: Robert LaVigne was an American Postwar & Contemporary artist who was born in 1928. Numerous key galleries and museums such as John Natsoulas Center for the Arts have featured Robert LaVigne's work in the past.Robert LaVigne's work has been offered at auction multiple times. In MutualArt’s artist press archive, Robert LaVigne is featured in Sotheby’s Bent. Sale Celebrates Worldpride, a piece from WHITEWALL in June 2019.
person.note: is a painter and stage designer, presently living in New York. He received the Obie Award for set design in 1968, for his sets and costumes for A Midsummer Night's Dream.
, the cover artist, lives in San Diego, California.

person.desc: Joanna Russ was an American writer, academic and feminist. She is the author of a number of works of science fiction, fantasy and feminist literary criticism such as How to Suppress Women's Writing, as well as a contemporary novel, On Strike Against God, and one children's book, Kittatinny.
person.note: is the author of Picnic On Paradise, and And Chaos Died, recently nominated for the Nebula Award of the Science Fiction Writers of America. She lives in Ithaca, New York, and teaches at Cornell University.

person.desc: James Sallis is an American crime writer who wrote a series of novels featuring the detective character Lew Griffin set in New Orleans, and the 2005 novel Drive, which was adapted into a 2011 film of the same name. Sallis began writing science fiction for magazines in the late 1960s.
person.note: ' book of stories and poetry, A Few Last Words, was published last fall. He is working on more poems, stories, a novel, and a book on American country and western music.

person.desc: Josephine Mary Howard was born in Halifax, Yorkshire, in 1935 and from the mid-60's produced a body of highly regarded science fiction novels and short stories under the name Josephine Saxton. Her 1986 novel Queen of the States was nominated for the 1987 Arthur C. Clarke Award. She lives in Warwickshire.
person.note: is the author of The Hieros Gamos Of Sam And An Smith. Her new novel, Vector For Seven, is scheduled to appear soon.

person.desc: Donald Edward Simpson (born 1961)[1] is an American comic book cartoonist and freelance illustrator, most noted as the creator of the series Megaton Man, Border Worlds, and Bizarre Heroes, as well as the official comic book adaption of King Kong. He also freelanced for nearly every major comic book publisher. His most widely seen work are the illustrations he created for Al Franken's 2003 bestseller, Lies and the Lying Liars Who Tell Them: A Fair and Balanced Look at the Right.
person.note: lives in Berkeley, California, where he draws, paints, and creates elegant machines.
lives in San Francisco. His collected poems will appear from the Grove Press this year, and he is presently writing a book-length prose work.

person.desc: Tom Veitch has been drawing and writing comics, novels, poetry and screenplays since the early 1970s. His comics work began in underground comix in San Francisco, where he teamed up with artist Greg Irons. They created underground characters such as 'Jumpin' Jack Flesh', 'Our Mutant Brothers and 'Vince Shazam'. Later, Tom would follow his brother Rick Veitch into mainstream comics. Together with Stephen R. Bissette, he co-created 'Grumm', the adventures of a fearless boy and his pet monster, but this comic was never published. Veitch wrote a personal homage to Robert Crumb in Monte Beauchamp's book 'The Life and Times of R. Crumb. Comments From Contemporaries (St. Martin's Griffin, New York, 1998).
person.note: commutes from New York to San Fran-cisco. His work has appeared in many poetry magazines and anthologies, and he is the co-author, with Ron Padg-ett, of the novel Star Gut.

person.desc: Kate Wilhelm was an American author. She wrote novels and stories in the science fiction, mystery, and suspense genres, including the Hugo Award–winning Where Late the Sweet Birds Sang. Wilhelm established the Clarion Workshop along with her husband Damon Knight and writer Robin Scott Wilson.
person.note: is the author of many novels and collections of stories. Her latest novel, Margaret And I is scheduled for publication this year.
